title: Government Houses of the British Empire and Commonwealth
text:
A Government House is any residence used by <a href="Governor-General">Governors-General</a>, <a href="Governor">Governor</a>s and <a href="Lieutenant-Governor">Lieutenant-Governor</a>s in the <a href="Commonwealth%20of%20Nations">Commonwealth</a> and the <a href="British%20Empire">British Empire</a>. Government Houses serve as the venue for Governors’ official business, as well as the many receptions and functions hosted by the occupant. Sometimes, the term "Government House" is used as a <a href="metonym">metonym</a> for the Governor or his office.
While a <a href="Government%20House">Government House</a> is the <a href="official%20residence">official residence</a> of a <a href="viceroy">viceroy</a> or governor who represents the <a href="monarch">monarch</a>, many Commonwealth nations now operate without the <a href="British%20Monarch">British Monarch</a> as <a href="Head%20of%20State">Head of State</a>. To avoid confusion, several of these nations refer to their <a href="presidential%20palace">presidential palace</a>s as a "State House" or "<a href="President%27s%20House%20%28disambiguation%29">President's House</a>".
When <a href="Queen%20Elizabeth%20II">Queen Elizabeth II</a> or a member of the <a href="Royal%20Family">Royal Family</a> visits a Commonwealth nation, they will often stay at the Government House, which is reported in the <a href="Court%20Circular">Court Circular</a>. This privilege is sometimes extended to other dignitaries, but usually arrangements are made for important non-royal visitors to be accommodated at hotels, or in accommodations provided by their own country's <a href="embassy">embassy</a> or <a href="consulate">consulate</a>.

After 1922, the Viceregal Lodge served as the official residence of the first two <a href="Governor-General%20of%20the%20Irish%20Free%20State">Governors-General</a> of the <a href="Irish%20Free%20State">Irish Free State</a>.
The <a href="Governor%20of%20Northern%20Ireland">Governor of Northern Ireland</a> resided in <a href="Hillsborough%20Castle">Hillsborough Castle</a>, which is, since 1973, the official residence of the <a href="Secretary%20of%20State%20for%20Northern%20Ireland">Northern Ireland Secretary</a>.
